replies.msg: but gunpowder works too if you have no choice

quote.msg: but gunpowder works too if you have no choice

replies.msg:
No, gunpowder doesn’t work in scenarios such as this.

The purpose of gunpowder is to generate lots of gas upon combustion for propelling a projectile. Heat generation is not the primary design goal of formulating gunpowder. The rate of combustion is.

When you burn gunpowder, gas is produced, lots of gas in fact. Because of the high rate of gas production, the gas is more likely to further distort the wound margins than being released to the outside in a controlled manner. Imaging having a mini-explosion inside your wound cavity, that’s what burning gunpowder would produce.

We have not even discussed whether gunpowder can still combust after becoming wet because of the blood, nor whether the oozing/ even squirting blood (very commonly observed in a nicked vein/ artery) would wash away the gunpowder. And there is also the potential systemic toxicity due to gunpowder getting into systemic circulation. So how practical is it?

Heating up a knife till it’s super hot, then using that as a make-shift electric cauteriser, would have a higher chance of success then attempting this Rambo manoeuvre or however you call it.
